Re: License #: CB820201514
Dear Ms. Keller:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
10/24/2024. An exit conference wa held with the agency on 10/28/2024. Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Rori Dodge-Pifer at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient
number of competent staff to carry out the provisions
covered by these rules. The workload for each staff
member may not be more than any of the following:
(a) Five social service workers per supervisor.
A review of staff caseloads did not show compliance with the rule:
• One adoption supervisor had 9 cases and was supervising 2 workers.
• Two foster care supervisors had caseloads of 9 and 16 respectively, and
were supervising 3 workers.
• A Licensing Supervisor had a caseload of 11 and was supervising 4 workers.
It is noted that the agency's executive director of adoption, director of foster care,
and director of licensing were also carrying caseloads of 5, 3, and 14 respectively.
CPA Rule 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient
number of competent staff to carry out the provisions
covered by these rules. The workload for each staff
member may not be more than any of the following:
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker
for purposes of providing direct services in foster care,
2

independent living, adoption, or post adoption services or
a combination thereof.
A review of caseworker’s caseloads showed one foster care worker had a caseload
of 16.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months
after the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
One of 16 employee records reviewed showed the employee's annual evaluation
due by 7/1/2024 was completed late on 10/2/2024.
Repeat Violation Established
Renewal 2023 CAP approved 11/20/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(4) An agency shall maintain an orientation and training

One of ten new employee records reviewed did not show documentation of

CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency the borrowing agency shall have a
record containing all the following:
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
One of three borrowed home records reviewed showed the orientation for the foster
parent occurred after the child's 4/11/2024 date of placement.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home.
3

(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency the borrowing agency shall have a
record containing all the following:
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed
by the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
One of three borrowed home records reviewed showed the foster parent signed the
foster parent/agency agreement after the child's 4/11/2024 date of placement.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all
the following information:
(c) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children
are interviewed, their last names may not be included in
the report.
One of four special evaluations reviewed did not show clear and consistent
documentation of the interviewer or place of the interview. Additionally, the special
evaluation report included the last names of two foster children.
Repeat Violation Established
Renewal 2023 CAP approved 11/20/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar

One of four special evaluations reviewed showed a 1/18/2024 special evaluation

(3) The agency shall document all the following in the

(g) Information about the child was shared with the new

(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,

(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents

parent or parents and foster parent that the information
in the parent-agency treatment plan and any other

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
R400.12306(3) Application request:
• The agency is apprised the documentation it uses to show proof of this
rule shall more clearly and definitively demonstrate that the application
was provided. If not, other methods shall be utilized and or added to show
such proof.
R400.12326(1) Borrowed Home:
• The agency was apprised documentation of the foster parent willingness
to accept the child shall be consistently documented for both foster
parents in a two-parent foster home.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400,12312- Foster Parent Training
• The agency was advised consistently documenting the number of hours a
foster parent’s view of a video equals, and listing that on a training sheet,
may aid it in showing compliance to the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
7

There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
This incident related to a foster home complaint where it was alleged the foster
parent pushed her foster son in the chest. During the special evaluation the foster
parent admitted to an incident where her subsititute caregiver hit the foster child’s
hand after the child grabbed the substitute caregiver’s arm. The subsititute
caregiver corroborated the foster parent’s statement. The foster home was found in
violation of the foster home behavior management rule and supervison rule for
using a substitute caregiver who had not been approved by the agency. A
corrective action plan was developed with the foster parent around not using
corporal punishment, and only using an approved subsitiute care provider.
The agency adhered to departmental standards and timeframes related to this
special evaluation. The agency’s actions appeared appropriate related to this
incident.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted one acceptable corrective action plan(CAP) during this
licensing period. This corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2023 Renewal
inspection. The agency received 13 citations in 2023 and 17 this year. Of the 17
rule violations received this year, two are repeat rule violations from 2023. The
agency implemented its corrective action plan and made progress with it as
demonstrated by the low number of repeat citations, and the low number of
individual cases cited per rule. The latter being just one case for all the citations,
except two.
The agency reported its efforts to totally complete its corrective action plan and to
maintain ongoing rule compliance was hampered by staffing issues. They reported
experiencing a number of staff departures and delays in hiring and maintaining
workers.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator's report dated 10/14/2024.
The administrator reported the main systematic barriers that continues to impact
rule/policy compliance has been the retention rate of foster care staff, as noted
prior. Additionally, the mandated child welfare institute training for new staff which
keeps these staff away from the office, does not allow agency to fully use them
until the completion of the training, and these staff appearing to not be adequately
prepared after nine weeks of training. The administrator also reported
MISACWIS, as well as CWLM as barriers to rule/policy compliance. The former
system due to its inaccurately displaying some standards, such as worker /parent
visits. The latter CWLM system due to the many fixes the system has made and
the high number of help desk that resulted which caused licensing reports to be
delayed or late.
8

Notwithstanding the challenges the agency reported, they indicated continuing all
efforts to hire new staff, and to gain and increase compliance. They reported the
corrective action had a positive impact on the agency in that it caused a greater
focus on various areas, such as special evaluations, and for it to examine where
training needs exist.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted a copy of it 2024 annual budget and 9/30/2023 independent
financial audit. A review of this information did not show concerns.
Staff Interviews
In addition to discussion with the chief administrator/adoption director, the licensee
designee, executive director of foster care & licensing, director of foster care,
licensing director, and two foster supervisors, I interviewed a licensing worker, two
foster care workers, adoption worker, and one foster supervisor.
The area of strengths reported by these staff related to there being good agency
communication; reminders to workers of due dates by supervisors, co-workers and
supervisory support; the agency’s efforts to educate its staff; its review of its CAP
with staff; and conducting case file reviews. Areas of growth reported related to
needing there to be less policing of works, more timely communication related to
financial/administrative changes, and improved communication between child
welfare and other agency components like residential, therapeutic services, and
adoption.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the agency's office site did not reveal any concerns or safety
issues. The agency has sufficient space and equipment for the staff; and files are
securely stored physically and electronically.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
